On My PS3 I get no sound! Perfect picture.

@adonaij & AnshulBansal
If the ripper were to provide you with 1920x1080 video, a lot of data would be lost encoding the black bars over and under the image itself for movies that are wider than the 16:9 format. It's actually better to have it less than 1080 high.

I can understand it may be hard to understand if you've never done any sort of digital photography, video editing or video encoding, but believe me, as long as a movie is 1920 wide, you're not losing a single pixel from the original picture. Rippers are just reducing the final file size by removing the black bars from the file as they are not needed.

The only loss in quality comes from the conversion from Blu-Ray's H264 or VC-1 codec to the X264 codec used in the MKV container (Which is why you can have a 90 minutes movie at only 6.5GB versus the BD source at 18GB).

Is this a re-encode of http://thepiratebay.org/torrent/6023025/Legend.of.the.Guardians.720p.Bluray.x264-CBGB ?  I'm looking at both, freezing on the same frame in each, and this one doesn't seem to have any more detail than the other, and the other might even look a bit better.  Hard to tell though.

Yeah, looks like it.  The NFO file is the same, with CBGB's ASCII art, only the encode numbers are different.  Neither mentions a source.

These others credit "1080p CBGB" as their source: http://thepiratebay.org/torrent/6046191/Legend_of_the_Guardians_2010_720p_BRRip_x264-HDLiTE , http://thepiratebay.org/torrent/6025681/Legend_Of_The_Guardians_2010_720p_BRRip_XviD_AC3-ViSiON , and http://thepiratebay.org/torrent/6025421/Legend_Of_The_Guardians_2010_720p_BRRip_XviD_AC3-ViSiON_BOZX
